Early Access Review

'Choose a planet' beckoned Gasp, offering me either the Moon or Mars.
Well, I thought, the Moon isn't a planet. It's a moon. But I'm not paying £1.99 blind to get to Mars right away so the Moon it is.
I crash land. Command tries to panic me over the radio regarding my dwindling oxygen levels and tells me to head for one of five markers. My choice. The situation looks... well, promising is a strong word but I'm not offended by the experience. Not yet.
Nearly fifteen minutes later, after CRAWLING over the surface of the Moon in what feels like excruciating real time while being battered every five feet by random space debris, my marker is within sight at the centre of a crater. I move towards it. As I attempt to enter the crater, an invisible barrier stops me. I become upset. I try to move around the perimeter of the forcefield. GASP responds by freezing me in place and continuing to batter me with space rocks. I leave before I can give it the satisfaction of killing me.
You can recreate this fun experience at home by attempting to run into a wall while a friend or family member throws rubble at the back of your head or you can check out my tragic journey below. Whatever you choose, please... don't let it be GASP's install button.

reviewText:
GASP.

Long winded / semi-comprehensive review.

The game is about 900 mb, give or take, and it didn't take long to install. Once you open the game, you're met with display options, but the graphics aren't impressive even on the highest setting. Starting this game in windowed mode may cause some problems. On the HUD, you're likely to receive some error messages like 'SetNextWeapon is not in VP Input Manager's buttons. You must add it for this button to work.' It obscures your (admittedly worthless) GPS module in the bottom lefthand corner. Poor coding, but jokes on you, there are no weapons.

The menu music is exactly the same as the music in game. A 20 second dark ambience loop that is poorly looped because it clips at its origin. Also, whichever menu option you select will immediately reset the loop.

Now once you hit the play button, there's no backing out of this menu. You must choose Moon, or if you were compelled beyond belief with high expectations into purchasing it, Mars.


Alright, let's get rolling. First off, a really ominous (read: not really) text-based message pops up before you begin your journey, telling you that this game is not designed to hold your hand, and that once you die, you die. However, this is misleading as you can't actually die. More on that later.

On the Comms you hear an androgenyous voice, clearly not at all concerned for your safetly, tells you in a plaintive tone that you've crashed. I should note that the crash is IMPLIED, you don't actually see the crash, as there's no cinematic cutscene or anything. This supposed crashsite is just a poorly moddled white conical shape, tilted to its side on a rock because, you know, it crashed. No damage --  nothing. How exquisite.

The androgynous voice tells you that your oxygen levels are limited and because basically your visor got f*cked up in the crash, and it actually shows you 5 different signals to follow instead of one leading you back to the LZ. It's up to you to run in one direction for an hour to find out which one is the real LZ! He/she offers some coy words of advice, telling you that you should choose wisely and hope for the best, because he/she THINKS the oxygen won't hold out long after he/she told you the oxygen levels are limited in the first place. Wow, as an astronaut I never, ever, in a million light years never would have rationally came to that conclusion. Thanks for all the help.

Controls are pretty straightforward. WASD to move, Spacebar to jump, and RMB to zoom in. Funnily enough, you can either tap the spacebar for a quick jump and fall, or hold down Spacebar to jump to new heights, and glide down until you release the spacebar, at which point you fall flat downward in place. Yep, this is typically how real life moon physics work, as I understand it.

Whoa sh*t! What was that? Giant bouncy balls that are all the same shape falling from the sky? Nobody briefed me on this? Oh they're supposed to be meteor showers that are hellbent on killing the player astronaut at all costs. Just like the developers, we all know the Moon is much bigger and has much more gravity than Earth, so of course it's safe to assume that the planet is getting consistently, CONSISTENTLY pelted with showers, no, blankets of meteors. I began to ask myself if this was indeed the much anticipated Chicken Little walking simulator on the moon that I've been hearing so much about?

You can SEE the meteors spawn in the skybox. On your HUD you get periodic warning text when a meteor is in the vicinity of your player. Each direct hit with a falling meteor reduces your oxygen, yes, your OXYGEN levels by 10% a pop. Oxygen decrements on its own, I didn't bother really counting the time between % points, but I knew I lost a point of O2 because my visor filled with blood. Yes, your f*cking visor gets splattered with blood when you lose an O2 point. Remember the last time you held your breath and blood poured out of your face? Neither do I.

The first signal I reached was a big disappointment. It was just a radio-like object with a light emitter on the ground. I couldn't actually do anything with it, such as interact or pick it up. So I had to walk for another 20 minutes to try and get to the next point on my HUD while dodging" these space balls.

On my journey I went from %100 Oxygen to %Dead oxygen (no

ooooo! its a bouncy castle!

The GASP Experiment:
It’s the scenario where the practical joker stands at the street corner staring up in the sky when a passerby stops becomes curious then also looks up and then the next does the same until you have a crowd of people staring up at nothing, the joker laughs quietly to himself and leaves. You are left with a crowd of people looking at nothing in the hope that something interesting happens.  There you have social experiment of 'GASP'.

Game Play Review:

Astronauts are the best of the best.  Well in this game you are not a member of that group, you probably got to the moon by winning a charity auction.  As you will soon discover you don’t have the Right Stuff.

Options:
The developers spared you from a long tutorial by incorporating the same game mechanics you learned from your first PC game back in the 90's.
You can switch between appalling or disappointing graphics in the options but the two cord background music loop is there for your enjoyment for the duration of the game unless you mute your whole system.

Gameplay:
You find yourself crashed on the moon miles away from your crewmates, leaking oxygen from your spacesuit and pummeled by falling objects; objects that must be from the asteroid remnants from the movie Armageddon due to their alarming frequency.
*a special note here, if you find yourself on Mars then you bought the DLC and should be excluded from any future Steam purchases.

Your physical attributes preclude you from avoiding any of the falling debris each finding its way into your face; all lacking the mass to disturb the dust on the moon’s surface but are somehow able to send you sprawling.

In your headset the teenaged cheerleader mission control assigned as your communication officer explains your situation and the urgency to reach the other crew members for your very survival is at stake instilling in you the sense of utter futility and the need to be in an altogether different game and scenario.
Thus your journey begins.

Oh but before you can commence your adventure the cheerleader gives the you a Monty Hall scenario by offering you 5 objectives to choose from, 4 lead to zonks and the fifth may be 'the big deal of the day or your untimely death.  You feel the suspense tingling through you!

You start your journey and after a short time your mind’s eye pictures the game developers sitting over you as gods laughing at your futile attempt to traverse their landscape in the effort to reach one of the signal locations. First the devGods chuckle as they throw meteors at your face to divert you from the chosen path. If the devGods find that you are truly determined to follow this path they will test your faith for they'll smit you with an invisible wall at just the right angle that you believe you can circumvent the wall and continue advancing to your destination.  When you realize that there is no going around the barrier you decide to retrace your path but the devGods say "Oh neigh neigh" and drop another invisible wall across the return path.  You know the devGods are wetting themselves by now as they prepare for the coop degras having trapped you.  Now they have their fish-in-a-barrel they throw stones at until you are %DEAD but that is not the end for they are devGods and they say that %DEAD is only mostly dead which is not completely dead thus you remain their trapped pray for eternity.

Game is badly broken. This shouldn't be early access, heck this isn't even alpha quality.

There are several game breaking bugs that need to be fixed. The goal of the game is to reach other people after some sort of spaceship crash.  There's a teeny problem with this, there are invisible walls that prevent you from reaching some of the objective markers. There are also places where the texturres are so dark that you stop moving without knowing it.

Other more minor issues. The game also seems to randomly stop reading inputs. The textures flash different colors. You have magically appearing and disappearing space debris, though it seems to have no effect on you. Hud colors make text impossible to read on teextures. And the list goes on. I would also nitpick on improper use of terminology but....

Normally I wouldn't complain about a simple game, but in this case it doesn't even do the one thing it's suppose to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay... I may have just logged 23 minutes of this game so far, but I might as well as talk about this...

I'll go ahead and start with an overview. This game is essentially about an astronaut who crashed his ship on the moon (or Mars) and is stranded. With five signals spread all across the surface of the moon (or Mars), and your O2 tank running low, you need to make the long and perilous treck across, and hope you can survive an onslaught of space rocks plummiting to the ground.

Well, where do I begin? There are so many good and bad things about this game. And with a story like that, you would think it would be stellar. An absolute gem. And to some extent, it is! It is a decent time waister, so if you're bored, you can boot this up for a quick go. Not to mention, it is pretty. It captures the near barren landscape of the moon rather well.
Also, lets not forget the setup. As I thought about it, it is a scary thought, getting stranded on a lunar body, millions of miles from Earth, with NO way of communicating than one out of five strange signals. It's pretty terrifying.

However, there are bugs in this game. LOTS. One that I can see that is pretty game breaking is God's invisible wall, which stops you after a certain point. You get blocked, and you can either return, or simply just return to the space craft and wait for your oxygen to run out.

Speaking of the oxygen, that is a nice feature. And it's depletion is rather slow, making for enough time to get to your objective. However, once you recah an objective, you gotta figure out what to do. I haven't found a single button on my keyboard that allows for you to interact, so that's pretty bad.

A fun feature is the meteor shower. That's pretty fun. Running across the moon (or Mars) as large meatballs of rock rain down from the sky is pretty fun. That is, if you figure how to run. There isn't a sprint mechanic, and that's understandable, space suit, duh. But, yeah, it's still nice.

People have said that they've been getting hit by invisible meteors. Not really, it's just your oxygen going down. I know, seems strange, as it's the smae thing as a damage indicator, but oh well.

Since this is in Early access, I say don't be too harsh on it, but don't be a panzy about what you think. It may (or may not) get better by the time it's fully released. As it stands now, yeah, I like it. Do I recommend it? Yeah, you can try it out, give a run through. It's free, looks decent, and runs pretty decently, even on my PC, so, it's worth a try. Just don't get Mars unless your REALLY want to, it's $3.00.
